newsitem.title: SPAIN: BASKETBALL-YUGOSLAVIA FAVOURITES TO RETAIN EUROPEAN CROWN.
newsitem.headline: BASKETBALL-YUGOSLAVIA FAVOURITES TO RETAIN EUROPEAN CROWN.

text.p: Yugoslavia hope to confirm their place as the number two side in world basketball by retaining their title in the European championships beginning this week.
Yugoslavia -- runners-up to the all-powerful U.S. side in the Atlanta Olympics -- start as favourites, although the tournament promises to be one of the most open in years.
All but two or three of the 16 sides competing are in with a chance of a medal, or one of the five places that give automatic qualification for the next world championships.
Despite some injury problems Yugoslavia, who took the trophy on their return to international competition two years ago, are still the team to beat.
Coach Zeljko Obradovic will particularly miss Vlade Divac and Zarko Paspalj.
However Obradovic, who will be on familiar territory after his time in Spain coaching Real Madrid, should have no problems in steering his side past Group C rivals Latvia, Italy and Poland.
Although host teams have done well in recent competitions, a home victory this year would be a real surprise.
Spain, who have never won the competition, will be hoping to avoid a repeat of their disastrous 1992 Olympic campaign, although Lolo Sanz's team have looked unconvincing in warm-up matches.
"We lost to home sides in Germany and Greece in the last two European competitions, so at least we can't do that again," joked Sanz.
Spain play in Group D alongside Croatia, Yugoslavia's most obvious rival for the gold.
Croatia took silver in Barcelona 92, but the success prompted a drain of star performers to the NBA.
With the American sides increasingly reluctant to release their players, the Croats will have to look for substitutes for U.S.-based stars Dino Radja, Toni Kukoc, Stojan Vrankovic and Zan Tabak.
Nevertheless, an ageing German side, surprise winners as hosts in 1993, and Ukraine are unlikely to put up much resistance to Croatia in the opening phase.
Group A promises to produce fireworks with the confrontation of two much-improved teams, Greece and Turkey, traditional rivals both on and off the court
Bosnia and perennial challengers Russia complete the group.
Group B, with Israel, Lithuania, Slovenia and France, is perhaps the most open of the four.
Lithuania, on paper the strongest of the four, have been weakened by the absence of two players who have proved vital in previous campaigns, Arvidas Sabonis and Saraunus Marciulionis.
The tournament begins with Tuesday's opening ceremony.
Competition proper starts on Wednesday.
Groups:
Group A: Greece, Bosnia-Herzogovina, Russia, Turkey
Group B: Lithuania, Slovenia, France, Israel
Group C: Yugoslavia, Latvia, Italy, Poland
Group C: Croatia, Ukraine, Spain, Germany.
Schedule:
24 June: opening ceremony
25 - 27 June: first phase
29 June - 1 July: second phase
4 July: quarter-finals
5 July: semifinals
6 July: final
